parts.text: Hi there! How can I help you today?

This code represents a simple web page with expanding cards. Let's break down each file:

**1. `index.html`:**

*   **Structure:** Defines the basic HTML structure of the webpage.
    *   `<!DOCTYPE html>`, `<html>`, `<head>`, `<body>` are standard HTML tags.
*   **Head:**
    *   `<meta>` tags:  Provide metadata about the document (character set, viewport settings).
    *   `<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" />`: Links the HTML to the CSS stylesheet (`style.css`) for visual styling.
    *   `<title>Expanding Cards</title>`: Sets the title of the webpage that appears in the browser tab.
*   **Body:**
    *   `<div class="container">`:  A container element to hold the expanding cards. The class `container` will be styled in the CSS.
    *   `<div class="panel ...">`: These are the individual expanding card elements.  Each one:
        *   Has the class `panel`.
        *   Has an inline `style` attribute to set the `background-image` of the card.  The images are fetched from Unsplash (a stock photo website).
        *   The *first* panel also has the class `active` which is used to designate a default active panel on page load.
        *   Contains an `<h3>` heading with text like "Explore The World," "Wild Forest," etc., which will be revealed when the panel is active.
    *   `<script src="script.js"></script>`:  Includes the JavaScript file (`script.js`) which will handle the interactivity of the cards.

**2. `style.css`:**

*   **CSS Reset:** The `* { box-sizing: border-box; }` line helps with consistent sizing across browsers.
*   **Body Styles:**
    *   `font-family`: Sets the font to "Muli" (imported from Google Fonts).
    *   `display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;`: Centers the content vertically and horizontally.
    *   `height: 100vh;`: Makes the body take up the full viewport height.
    *   `overflow: hidden;`: Prevents scrollbars from appearing if the content overflows.
    *   `margin: 0;`: Removes default body margin.
*   **Container Styles:**
    *   `display: flex;`: Enables Flexbox layout for the container.
    *   `width: 90vw;`: Sets the container's width to 90% of the viewport width.
*   **Panel Styles:**
    *   `background-size: cover; background-position: center; background-repeat: no-repeat;`: Styles the background image to cover the entire panel, be centered, and not repeat.
    *   `height: 80vh;`: Sets the height to 80% of the viewport height.
    *   `border-radius: 50px;`: Rounds the corners of the panels.
    *   `color: #fff;`: Sets the text color to white.
    *   `cursor: pointer;`: Changes the cursor to a pointer on hover.
    *   `flex: 0.5;`:  Initial flex grow/shrink/basis value.  This is the key to the expanding effect. Inactive panels will take up a small portion of the container.
    *   `margin: 10px;`: Adds spacing around the panels.
    *   `position: relative;`:  Allows absolute positioning of the `<h3>` heading within the panel.
    *   `-webkit-transition: all 700ms ease-in;`: Creates a smooth transition effect for all properties over 700ms with an "ease-in" timing function.
*   **Panel Heading Styles:**
    *   `font-size`: Sets the font size.
    *   `position: absolute; bottom: 20px; left: 20px;`: Positions the heading at the bottom-left of the panel.
    *   `margin: 0;`: Removes default heading margin.
    *   `opacity: 0;`: Initially hides the heading.
*   **`panel.active` Styles:**
    *   `flex: 5;`: Makes the active panel take up a much larger portion of the container, creating the "expanding" effect.
*   **`panel.active h3` Styles:**
    *   `opacity: 1;`: Makes the heading visible when the panel is active.
    *   `transition: opacity 0.3s ease-in 0.4s;`: Creates a smooth fade-in effect for the heading's opacity.
*   **Media Query:**
    *   `@media (max-width: 480px)`: Applies the following styles only when the screen width is 480px or less (for mobile devices).
    *   Hides the 4th and 5th panels to improve the layout on smaller screens.

**3. `script.js`:**

*   **Select Panels:**
    *   `const panels = document.querySelectorAll('.panel')`: Selects all elements with the class "panel" and stores them in a NodeList called `panels`.
*   **Event Listeners:**
    *   `panels.forEach(panel => { ... })`: Iterates through each panel element.
    *   `panel.addEventListener('click', () => { ... })`: Adds a click event listener to each panel.
        *   When a panel is clicked:
            *   `removeActiveClasses()`: Calls the `removeActiveClasses` function to remove the "active" class from all panels.
            *   `panel.classList.add('active')`: Adds the "active" class to the clicked panel.
*   **`removeActiveClasses()` Function:**
    *   `panels.forEach(panel => { ... })`: Iterates through each panel element.
    *   `panel.classList.remove('active')`: Removes the "active" class from each panel.

**In Summary:**

This code creates a webpage with a row of image panels.  Initially, all panels are narrow. When a panel is clicked:

1.  The "active" class is removed from all panels.
2.  The "active" class is added to the clicked panel.

The CSS styles, particularly the `flex` property, are then used to visually expand the active panel, making it larger than the others and revealing its heading. The JavaScript handles the user interaction (the click events) and updates the classes to control which panel is active.
